title: 111_s303
content: The Act titled "Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2009" is being reauthorized by amending Section 11 of the Act from 1999. The amendment removes the provision for the Act to cease being effective 8 years after enactment. Additionally, a website related to federal grants is established. The Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1999 is amended to establish a public website for federal grant information, including grant announcements, eligibility statements, application requirements, and grant purposes. The Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1999 is amended to establish a public website for federal grant information, including grant announcements, eligibility statements, application requirements, funding agencies, and deadlines. The website allows grant applicants to search for grants, apply, manage, track, report, and provide certifications and assurances online. The Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1999 is amended to establish a public website for federal grant information, allowing grant applicants to search for grants, apply, manage, track, report, and provide certifications and assurances online. Subsection (g) is amended to exclude actions related to establishing the required website. SEC. 4. REPORT ON IMPLEMENTATION. The Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1999 is amended to evaluate implementation. The Director must submit a report to Congress every 2 years regarding the implementation of the Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2009. The report should include a list of grants, federal agencies providing financial assistance, and agencies involved in the process. The Director must submit a report to Congress every 2 years on the implementation of the Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2009. The report should include a list of compliant federal agencies, descriptions of their compliance extent, exempted agencies with explanations and certifications for exemptions, and common application forms. The Director must provide a report to Congress every 2 years on the implementation of the Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2009. This report includes lists of common application forms and requirements for non-Federal entities to apply for and report on funding from multiple Federal financial assistance programs. The Director must report to Congress every 2 years on the implementation of the Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2009, including efforts to collaborate with Federal agencies and disburse financial assistance to non-Federal entities. Subsequent reports must also include details on systems used for financial assistance disbursement. The Director must report to Congress every 2 years on the progress of the Federal Government in meeting the goals of the Act and implementing the strategic plan. The report should also include a compilation of reports submitted during the applicable period. The Director must report to Congress every 2 years on the progress of the Federal Government in meeting the goals of the Act and implementing the strategic plan. The report should also include a compilation of reports submitted during the applicable period, defined as the most recent full fiscal year before the report for the first submission, and for subsequent reports, the period from the date of the last report to the current report date. SEC. 5. STRATEGIC PLAN. The Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1999 is amended to include a new section on a strategic plan. The Director must submit a strategic plan to Congress within 18 months of the enactment of the Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2009. The plan should identify suitable federal financial assistance programs for common applications and reporting forms, as well as common aspects that can be standardized. It should also highlight any necessary changes in law to achieve the goals of the Act. The Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2009 requires the development of an electronic, web-based process for managing Federal financial assistance. This process includes the ability to apply for assistance, track application status and payments, report on the use of funds, and provide certifications and assurances. The Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2009 requires full compliance by Federal agencies, creating common applications and financial reporting forms for various assistance programs. The Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2009 mandates the establishment of common applications, financial reporting forms, and requirements for federal assistance programs across different agencies. It also requires the development of mechanisms to ensure compatibility between federal and state systems for data exchange, as well as common certifications and assurances for programs with similar purposes. The Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2009 requires the establishment of common applications, financial reporting forms, and requirements for federal assistance programs. It also mandates consultation with non-Federal entities and the development of plans by Federal agencies to carry out their responsibilities under the strategic plan. The Federal agency must establish clear performance objectives, timelines, and improve communication with non-Federal entities during the implementation of the strategic plan. Consultation with non-Federal entities is required during the development and implementation of the agency's plan. Reporting is due within 2 years for agencies without exemptions. The Federal agency must report on progress towards achieving plan objectives every 2 years until 15 years after the enactment of the Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 2009. A technical amendment is made to the Act regarding reporting requirements. A technical amendment is made to the Act regarding reporting requirements. Passed the Senate March 17, 2009.
